Title.evidence: Carotid Revascularization Endarterectomy versus Stenting Trial (CREST): A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either CAS or CEA.

Participants.evidence: This multicenter randomised controlled trial involved 2,502 patients eligible based on carotid artery stenosis criteria.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either CAS or CEA.

Objective.evidence: The CREST trial aimed to compare the periprocedural stroke and death (S+D) rates between carotid artery stenting (CAS) and carotid endarterectomy (CEA) in patients with carotid artery stenosis.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the periprocedural S+D rate, measured over a 30-day period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Due to the nature of the procedures, blinding was not feasible.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 1,251 patients were assigned to each treatment group.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis followed an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: For lesions â‰¥12.85 mm, CAS showed a higher S+D risk compared to CEA (OR = 3.42; 95% CI, 1.19-9.78).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were more frequent in the CAS group, but specific frequencies and severities were not detailed.

Funding.evidence: This study was funded by the National Institutes of Health.
